review.title: German in Flux: Detecting Metaphoric Change via Word Entropy
review.abstract: This paper explores the information-theoretic measure entropy to detect metaphoric change, transferring ideas from hypernym detection to research on language change. We also build the first diachronic test set for German as a standard for metaphoric change annotation. Our model shows high performance, is unsupervised, language-independent and generalizable to other processes of semantic change.

sections.heading: 3 Metaphoric Change
sections.text: Metaphorical change plays a fundamental role in semantic change (cf. e.g. Ferraresi, 2014, p. 15). In the framework of Conceptual Metaphor Theory (Lakoff and Johnson, 1980), the metaphorical effect can be described as an illustration from a source domain to a target domain. According to Koch's terminology (2016, p. 24), innovative change of meaning is in contrast to reductive change of meaning where the existing meaning MA (the resource concept) of a word acquires a new meaning MB (the target concept). Metaphorical change is then a subcategory of innovative change of meaning where MB is related by similarity or a reduced comparison with MA (cf. Koch, 2016, p. 47, and also Steen, 2010, p. 10). While language is often used ad hoc in a non-literal change of meaning (in the discourse), not every one of these uses constitutes an instance of metaphorical change. sections.heading: 3.1 Distributional Properties
sections.text: As Bybee (2015, p. 258) notes, it is also common for "metaphorical changes in meaning to produce polysemy" (p. 199, their italics). Campbell (1998, p. 258) describes this effect as "extensions in the meaning of a word" caused by metaphorical changes. It is only logical to assume that such extensions in the range of meaning imply an extension into the realm of linguistic contexts in which a word occurs. This expansion distinguishes words from semantically stable words, but also from words that change in a reductive manner.

sections.heading: 5 Entropy
sections.text: In hypernym recognition, a number of established metrics compare the semantic generality of words based on their distributional generality (Weeds and Weir, 2003; Clarke, 2009; Kotlerman et al., 2009). One promising candidate appears to be the word entropy introduced in Santus (2013) and Santus et al. (2014). Among other benefits, word entropy is independently measurable over time, avoiding the problem of vector spatial alignment.

sections.heading: 5.2 Other Measures
sections.text: Word Frequency. In terms of frequency, a similar argument can be made as in Section 3.1: If a word acquires a new meaning and can be applied to a wider range of entities, then we expect the word to be used more frequently. Furthermore, it is known that certain types of semantic changes correlate with frequency. For example, desemantisation is accompanied by a sharp increase in frequency (cf. Bybee, 2015, p. 133). For this purpose, we use the frequency of a word w as the baseline for word entropy (in parallel to the practice of hypernym recognition). sections.heading: 7 Evaluation
sections.text: As with Gulordava and Baroni (2011) or Hamilton et al. (2016b), we evaluate the performance of the metrics by comparing their predictions in a corpus with a gold standard. Our gold standard is the rank of the target words in Table 1, which are obtained by annotations. We obtain the predictions of the metrics for the target words by first calculating their values in atime period 1 before the starting point of the change and in a period 2 thereafter. Then, we calculate the difference d in the values between period 1 and 2 for each target word and order the target words further. Next, we calculate the ranking correlation between each of these predicted rankings and the gold rank as a measure of performance. Period 1 is usually the century before and 2 centuries after the century of change, e.g. (1739) is compared in 1600-1700 and 1800-1900. (Only for targets from 1800-1900, the time interval 2 is different, i.e. the corpus we can only use in the text parts).

sections.heading: 9 Conclusion
sections.text: As Bybee (cf. 2015, p. 197) puts it, generalization and specialization are two fundamental principles of meaning change. We proposed a12Hauptmann, Gerhart: Der Biberpelz. Berlin, 1893.way to detect metaphorical changes based on semantic generality, and built a test set for the evaluation of mathematical models of metaphorical changes in German. We proposed an annotation method that is strictly derived from comparable synchronous work, and showed that annotators can have a reasonable agreement. Different distributional metrics based on the information theory concept of entropy were compared with the annotator judgments, and it was found that the crude word entropy was strongly and significantly correlated with the gold rank in different environments, unlike most other entropy metrics and frequency.

metadata.abstractText: This paper explores the informationtheoretic measure entropy to detect metaphoric change, transferring ideas from hypernym detection to research on language change. We also build the first diachronic test set for German as a standard for metaphoric change annotation. Our model shows high performance, is unsupervised, language-independent and generalizable to other processes of semantic change.
